text: Security can feel overwhelming,
so to help out, we put together a list of ten
tactical and strategic security items to improve in your AWS environment.
Diverse hiring and training
A broad range of perspectives makes
us stronger as an industry. Reflect on communities you serve, and invest in robust training
for employees who embody your culture.
Use AWS Organizations
With service control policies
in AWS Organizations, you can replace reactive
controls with preventative ones, a much better
place to reside for your security posture.
Understand your usage
Deeply understand your environment.
Use AWS Security Hub to identify what requires attention.
First measure, then improve!
Use cryptography services
Encryption can be the last line of defense.
Data that’s being improperly accessed
should still be protected via
encryption protocols.
Federation for human access
Use AWS Security Token Service
to grant temporary limited-privilege
credentials for authentication and AWS Single Sign-On to manage access
across accounts and applications from a single portal.
Block public access on your account
With the Amazon S3 “Block Public Access” feature, new buckets and access points
don’t allow public access. This allows you to be intentional with your data permissions!
Edge protect external resources
Protect the resources you have nearer to the internet in your
architecture with services like Amazon CloudFront, WAF,
and API Gateway.
Patch and measure
Review our blogs and whitepapers to integrate automation of your
patching program through AWS Systems Manager.
Automating manual processes
frees your people up for high-judgement activities.
No hard/soft defense
We want you to have a multi-layered
defense strategy. Make things difficult on
potential adversaries, don’t rely on just
one service or tool.
Transparent leadership reviews
Be optimistic and accountable,
and be the group that works with teams to make
security easier. Make sure leadership
stays aware of security projects and opportunities!
For more information and detailed processes on how to implement these
ten tips, please go to the AWS Security Blog.
